title: Why more new couples are at risk of paying thousands in 'romance tax' after moving in together
text:
New partners are increasingly at risk of lumping themselves with unexpected tax charges that require them to repay child benefit income, as cohabiting unmarried couples are now the fastest growing family type.

It follows calls from the independent Office for Tax Simplification (OTS) to review child benefit and the “high income benefit charge”, which experts have dubbed “a tax on romance”.

More than 7 million families claim child benefit, available since the Seventies. However, because of the introduction of the charge in 2013, just over one in 10 of these families is forced to either opt out of receiving their benefits altogether or pay back some or all of the benefits they have received –...
